@quinnnorton For a surprising number of young people (where it's me being surprised), I think their sexual orientation is 'Whatever', and trying to identify which categories are really real or stably unchanging over time is itself a category error.

@quinnnorton So to say pansexuals are 'just' bisexuals implies that the newer term is merely a relabel for a largely unchanging category. I used to believe that, but I stopped, because I think the kids I see today are just much less identitarian about the issue.

@quinnnorton But after watching my kids navigate this, I've come to believe that many of the labels I grew up with were themselves created by that same oppression. 

The growth of LGBTQIA+ designations suggests not completeness but instability.

@quinnnorton Call that the Stefani Germanotta Thesis, it's what I grew up with: Oppression of gays and lesbians was wrong because it was interfering with their right to express some core and largely immutable part of their identity.

@quinnnorton I used to think that, but I don't anymore. 

Having watched my kids go through adolescence and seeing them try on various labels, I've now decided my old beliefs -- "People have stable, deeply coded attractions", roughly -- was wrong.

@charlesarthur @paulmorriss @TheOverspill I did a bunch of scenario work in the aughts, and learned that when the sponsoring organization characterizes what you're doing as a 'moonshot', it meant they didn't understand their own circumstances, *and* they didn't understand how we actually got to the moon.

@charlesarthur @paulmorriss @TheOverspill Yeah, and the disappointment comes from learning how much circumstances matter. Both the moonshot and the iPhone had a technological base already worked out - neither rockets nor mobiles were new - so vision and talent were enough. 

Most projects don't have that advantage.

@charlesarthur @paulmorriss @TheOverspill I still think the iPhone and W95 were highly context dependent. No consumer OS or mobile phone has been as widely and rapidly adopted since those respective launches. 

So I don't think you can just announce in advance that you're going to have an iPhone moment.

@charlesarthur @paulmorriss @TheOverspill Win95 was the only contender, for sure, and also reformed a previously existing hardware category into something the average person might want, so yeah, you're right, and I'll instead say there are few iPhone moments, and Windows 95 is on that very list.

@charlesarthur @paulmorriss @TheOverspill There are no other iPhone moments. 

It was a miracle of technologies waiting to be exploited, a weak telco ready to cave, and visionary design. 

Even Apple never, in a half century, launched another product like that.

Saying 'iPhone moment' is as dumb as saying 'moonshot'
